The Irish National Tide Gauge Network is an on-going development involving the Marine Institute and a number of organisations in the public and private sectors to develop a permanent tidal monitoring infrastructure, ultimately consisting of between 35 and 40 stations.

COARDS, CF-1.4, Unidata Dataset Discovery v1.0

The Irish National Tide Gauge Network is an on-going development involving the Marine Institute and a number of organisations in the public and private sectors to develop a permanent tidal monitoring infrastructure, ultimately consisting of between 35 and 40 stations.
Irish National Tide Gauge Network River Gauges
Irish Marine Institute Connemara Model CONN2D
Irish Marine Institute Connemara Model CONN3D

The ROMS model uses the so-called sigma vertical coordinate system which is terrain-following (i.e. thickness of levels vary with total water depth within the model domain). Therefore, in the case of the Connemara model, the altitude Dimension does not refer to depth, but to model level where 1 is the bottom level and 20 is the level at the sea surface. Level 10/11 is approximately mid water but the other model levels can not be ascribed to any single depth level.

The wind vane points into the oncoming wind and the 10 minute average wind direction is recorded.Reported Hourly
The average wind speed (knots) for 10 minutes. Reported Hourly
The maximum wind speed measured over 3 seconds. Reported Hourly

wave height is calcluated as four times the RMS (Root Mean Square Value) of the wave. This value then gives you the change in height. The sensor measures this for 17.5 minutes and then takes an average.
A record of 17.5 minutes of the number of times a wave passes through mean water level in an upward direction.
COARDS, CF-1.4, Unidata Dataset Discovery v1.0
Sea Surface Swell Wave Zero upcrossing Period
The zero upcrossing period is defined as the time interval between consecutive occasions on which the surface height passes upward above the mean level. Swell waves are waves on the ocean surface.
Sea Surface Height of the highest wave
mean direction of sea water velocity
acoustic current meter mean current direction, defined as direction the water particles are moving towards

Dirp Direction for waves at peak of wave energy spectrum from which the waves are coming
Dsprp Directional spread of waves at peak of wave energy spectrum
Hm0 (significant wave height) derived from wave energy spectrum
Te Energy period derived from spectral moments, m-1 and m0
Tm01 (mean wave period) derived from spectral moments, m0 and m1
Tm02 (mean wave period) derived from spectral moments, m0 and m2
Tp Wave period of waves at peak of wave energy spectrum

Hmax - Maximum wave height measured during observation period
THmax - Period of maximum wave height measured during observation period
Havg - Average height of all the upcrossing waves measured during observation period
Tavg - Average period of all the upcrossing waves measured during observation period
